usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
inertia: User should feel the center of mass located significantly forward from the handle grip point
outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
interactionDeduction: Users will grasp the slender wooden handle with a three-finger hook or precision grip—thumb on the inner rim of the handle, index and middle fingers wrapping the outer curve, ring finger optionally supporting the bottom. The wrist rotates the mug toward the mouth, tilting about 45–90° to pour liquid. Because the mug’s center of mass (especially when filled) sits forward of the handle, users will feel a nose-heavy torque that must be countered by tightening their grip and slightly cocking the wrist. After sipping, they reverse the tilt and may place the mug down by lowering the forearm in a gentle arc. Haptically, they will mostly sense the handle’s 2 cm-diameter round wooden rod, the slight ridge where the handle attaches to the metal band, and the inertial shift of sloshing liquid. No significant deformation occurs; the outline stays rigid.

usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip with about 3cm diameter
interactionDeduction: Users employ a power grip around the 3 cm-diameter wooden haft—palm fully wrapped, thumb curled. For heavy swings, the dominant hand anchors near the base while the other hand may slide mid-haft and then release just before impact, mimicking realistic two-handed chopping. The motion involves large shoulder and elbow arcs, accelerating and decelerating a head-heavy mass that tries to continue forward after the arms stop, so users feel pronounced inertia in the blade end. On contact with a virtual target, the blade appears to bite and stop while the handle rebounds slightly, requiring the user to brace and possibly pull back. Minor wrist-angle adjustments allow precise targeting, but the axe remains rigid without noticeable flex.

usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip with about 3cm diameter
interactionDeduction: Most users will grasp the handle in a firm power grip near its end, thumb along the shaft, to maximize leverage. Swing paths are shorter than the axe—predominantly elbow-driven vertical or diagonal arcs for pounding. The head-heavy inertia produces a pendulum feel: once set into motion, the head wants to keep moving, requiring users to tighten forearm muscles to halt after impact. Feedback includes a sudden stop when the virtual head strikes a surface, followed by a slight recoil felt in the wrist and elbow. The handle outline stays cylindrical and hard; no perceptible flex or compliance is expected.

usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip with about 3cm diameter
interactionDeduction: Users hold the short 3 cm-diameter grip with a hybrid power/precision grasp—fingers wrapped but allowing index finger extension along the top for guidance. Cutting motions are sweeping semicircular arcs pulled toward the body, using wrist pronation and elbow flexion. Because the curved blade’s mass is distributed along its arc rather than a single point, the tool feels moderately forward-weighted but more balanced than an axe. As users slice, they sense a gliding resistance as the inner edge would shear through vegetation, followed by a quick follow-through. The blade remains rigid with no flex; contact is concentrated along the edge perimeter, so users keep fingers well back from the curve.
